document.docTitle: Gagones A-F: Six prenylated chalcones from the heartwood of Mansonia gagei

paragraph.docTitle:
Gagones A–F: Six prenylated chalcones from the heartwood of
Mansonia gagei

document.paragraph:
Huong Thi Thu Le
a, *
, Lam H. Nguyen b , Tuan H. Nguyen c , Van-Kieu Nguyen d, e , Ade Danova f , Thanh N. Truong g , Warinthorn Chavasiri h, **

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Chemistry , Ho Chi Minh City University of Education , 280 An Duong Vuong Street, District 5, Ho Chi Minh City , 700000, Viet Nam

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph:
Mansonia gagei J.R.Drumm.
Malvaceae Prenylated chalcones
Calculated NMR and ECD
Antioxidant
α- Glucosidase inhibitory activity
A B S T R A C T

Six undescribed prenylated chalcones gagones A–F were isolated from the acetone fraction of
Mansonia gagei
heartwood. Their structures were unambiguously established based on spectroscopic analysis (HRESIMS, 1D and 2D NMR), as well as comparison to literature data. Their absolute configurations were elucidated using DP4 and electronic circular dichroism calculations. Isolated compounds were evaluated for their inhibitory activity against α- glucosidase and DPPH assay. All of the tested compounds exhibited better activity than that of acarbose (IC 50 93.6 ± 0.5 μM). Among them, gagone D exhibited the highest α- glucosidase inhibitory with the IC 50 value of 3.6 ± 0.4 μM. For antioxidant activity, gagones A–C, and E showed more active than that of ascorbic acid (IC 50 30.2 ± 0.5 μM) with the IC 50 values of 13.2 ± 0.7, 20.1 ± 0.4, 19.3 ± 0.5 and 12.8 ± 0.2 μM, respectively.

Mansonia gagei J.R.Drumm. (Malvaceae)
is a medium-sized tree belonging to the
Mansonia
genus that comprises 5 species found in tropical countries, such as Myanmar and Thailand ( Tiew et al., 2002 ). In the past two decades, a variety of mansonones and mansorins have been isolated and characterised from chloroform fractions of
M. gagei
that present various bioactivities such as anticancer ( Baghdadi et al., 2018 ), antibacterial ( Mongkol and Chavasiri, 2016 ) and anti-melanogenesis ( Nishina et al., 2018 ).

Our current study showed that the acetone fraction exhibited excellent activity against α- glucosidase inhibitory activity, with 93.1% inhibition at 7.81 μg/mL, in comparison with acarbose (5.7%). After bioactivity screening, separation was carried out, and six unprecedented prenylated chalcones ( 1–6 ) were isolated from the acetone fraction of
M. gagei
heartwood ( Fig. 1 ). All prenylated chalcones were separated for the first time from nature. The isolation, structural elucidation and evaluation of α- glucosidase inhibitory and antioxidant activities are described here.

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: huongltt@hcmue.edu.vn (H.T.T. Le), warinthorn.c@chula.ac.th (W. Chavasiri).

subSection.paragraph: Gagone A (1) was isolated as a yellow amorphous powder. The (+)-HRESIMS spectrum depicted a protonated ion [M + H] + at m/z 441.1910 (calcd for C 25 H 29 O 7 , 441.1913), which was assigned to a molecular formula of C 25 H 28 O 7 with 12 double-bond equivalents. The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ) shows the presence of one olefinic proton at δ H 7.64 (1H, d, J = 2.5, H-7), three aromatic protons at 6.63 (1H, d, J = 2.0 Hz, H-2), 6.61 (1H, d, J = 2.0 Hz, H-6), and 6.56 (1H, s, H-3 ′ ), a methoxy at δ H 3.83 (3H, s), three methine protons, one methylene and four methyl groups. The 13 C NMR, in accordance with the HSQC spectrum of 1, suggested the presence of 25 carbons consisting of two carbonyls ( δ C 191.3 and 180.2), one methoxy ( δ C 56.7), four methyls ( δ C 22.6, 21.2, 20.3 and 17.2), seven methines ( δ C 138.8, 119.4, 112.0, 107.1, 46.6, 37.7 and 29.5), ten quaternary carbons ( δ C 161.4, 149.4, 146.4, 145.7, 141.7, 136.7, 133.1, 130.8, 128.1 and 125.9) and one methylene carbon ( δ C 32.5).

The planar structure of 1 was determined by a detailed analysis of its 2D NMR spectra, including correlation spectroscopy ( 1 H– 1 H COSY) and HMBC data ( Fig. 2 ). The appearance of a 1,3,4,5-substituted aromatic ring (A-ring) was identified by HMBC correlations from H-2 ( δ H 6.63) and H-6 ( δ H 6.61) to C-1 ( δ C 128.1), C-4 ( δ C 136.7) and C-7 ( δ C 138.8). In addition, the HMBC correlations of H-7 ( δ H 7.64) to C-2 ( δ C 112.0) and C- 6 ( δ C 107.1) accommodated 1,3,4,5-substituted on ring A in the following order: a methine, hydroxy, hydroxy and methoxy, respectively, further supported by the HMBC correlation between methoxy protons at δ H 3.83 to C-5 ( δ C 149.4).

Moreover, an isopropyl moiety located at C-5 ′ determined based on the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum that allowed spin system identified of H 3 -9 ′ / H-8 ′ /H 3 -10 ′ , further suggested by the HMBC correlation of methine proton H-8 ′ ( δ H 3.39), along with two methyl H 3 -9 ′ ( δ H 1.41) and H 3 -10 ′ ( δ H 1.31) to C-5 ′ ( δ C 130.8). Furthermore, the HMBC correlations of methyl proton H 3 -7 ′ ( δ H 2.42) to C-1 ′ ( δ C 125.9), C-2 ′ ( δ C 141.7) and C-3 ′ ( δ C 119.4); of methine proton H-8 ′ ( δ H 3.39) to C-4 ′ ( δ C 161.4), C-5 ′ ( δ C 130.8) and C-6 ′ ( δ C 145.7) determined the occurrence of a pentasubstituted aromatic ring moiety (B-ring). Additionally, the HMBC correlations of H 2 -1" ( δ H 3.33, 2.75) to C-7 ( δ C 138.8), C-8 ( δ C 133.1), C-9 ( δ C 191.3), C-6 ′ ( δ C 145.7) and C-2" ( δ C 37.7); H-2" ( δ H 3.66) to C-8, C-1 ′ ( δ C 125.9), C-6 ′ and C-1" ( δ C 32.5); H 3 -5"( δ H 0.92) to C-2", C-3"( δ C 46.6) and C-4" ( δ C 180.2) indicated the presence of a cyclohexanone ring with a 1- carboxyethyl moiety at C-2", further backed up by the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum allowing the spin system as H 2 -1"/H-2"/H-3"/H 3 -5". Finally, the geometric double bond at Δ
7 in
1 was determined to be E by the key NOESY correlation between H-6 and H-1" ( Fig. 3 ). Thus, the planar structure of 1 was fully established.

For the relative configuration, the NOESY spectrum exhibited the presence of the correlations between H-2"/H-3" instead of H-2"/H 3 -5" suggesting the cis orientation of these protons similar to those of pestaphthalides A and B ( Ding et al., 2008 ) and allowing the determination of two candidate enantiomers of 1, being (2" S ,3" S )-1a or (2" R ,3" R )-1 b, which were recognised through the calculated ECD spectrum. The absolute configuration of 1 was inferred by comparison between both predicted spectra with the experimental one, which showed an excellent fit for a (2" S ,3" S )-1a ( Fig. 4 ). Therefore, 1 was assumed to be (7 E,2" S , 3" S )-gagone A bearing an unprecedented 2-benzylidene-1-tetralone moiety similar to some synthetic compounds ( Liu et al., 2012 ; Maguire et al., 2019 ; Shih et al., 2000 ).

caption.paragraph: 1 H (500 MHz) NMR spectroscopic data of compounds 1–6 (CD OD) ( δ in ppm, J in Hz).
Fig. 2. Key HMBC and 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of compounds 1 and 2.
Fig. 3. Key NOESY correlations of compounds 1 and 2.

subSection.paragraph: Gagones B and C (2–3) showed the common molecular formula of C 25 H 28 O 7 , determined by HRESIMS, with 12 degrees of unsaturation similar to those of 1. The high similarity of their UV–vis spectra and the doubled resonances in the 1D NMR spectra ( Tables 1 and 2 ), especially in the 13 C NMR spectra of 2–3, implied that they share the same skeletons.

Compound 2 was obtained as a yellow amorphous powder. Despite their closely related molecular formulas, the examination of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra revealed some important structural differences with compound 1, including the occurrences of an oxymethine proton at δ H 5.57 (1H, s, H-7) and one carbonyl carbon ( δ C 215.4) instead of an olefinic proton ( δ H 7.64, in 1) and carboxyl carbon ( δ C 180.2, in 1), respectively, which recommended the formation of C-8-C-4" linkage of bicyclo [3.2.1]octane moiety, further suggested by the HMBC correlations of oxymethine proton H-7 ( δ H 5.57) to C-8 ( δ C 77.1), C-9 ( δ C 193.0) and C-4" ( δ C 215.4). Thus, the planar structure of 2 was elucidated as an unprecedented compound that contained bicyclo [3.2.1]octane unit occurring in both natural and synthetic compounds ( Kaysser et al., 2012 ; Ramachary et al., 2017 ; Sakoulas et al., 2012 ; Winkelmann et al., 2001 ). The key 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMBC, correlations of 1 and 2 are summarised in Fig. 2

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Experimental and calculated ECD spectra of 1 in MeOH.
13 C (125 MHz) NMR spectroscopic data of compounds 1 6 (CD OD) ( δ in ppm).

paragraph.tableNote: a Data were extracted from HMBC spectrum.

subSection.paragraph: Gagone C (3) was obtained as a pale yellow amorphous powder. Similarly to 2, it was also constructed from a bicyclo [3.2.1]octane unit. However, methyl protons were shifted upfield to δ H 0.71 (H 3 -5") in comparison to those of 2, suggesting that 3 was a diastereomer of 2 with the opposite configuration at C-3".

The positive-ion HRESIMS, with the ions [M + Na] + at m/z 477.1921 (calcd for C 26 H 30 O 7 Na, 477.1889, compound 4), at m/z 477.1918 (calcd for C 26 H 30 O 7 Na, 477.1889, compound 5) and m/z 491.2049 (calcd for C 27 H 30 O 7 Na, 491.2046, compound 6) showed that these isolates can be considered as a pair of isomers for 4 and 5 (C 26 H 30 O 7 ) and as a homologous series for 4 and 6 (C 26 H 30 O 7 , C 27 H 30 O 7 , respectively). The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 4 and 6 were also close to those of 2, with the significant differences being the appearance of a methoxy signal at δ H 3.18 (3H, s, 7-OCH 3 , δ C 57.8) in 4 and an ethoxy signal at [ δ H 1.08 (3H, t, J = 7.0 Hz), and δ H 3.38 (2H, m), δ C 15.6 and 65.5, respectively] in 6, which could be located at C-7 based on the HMBC correlations of methoxy proton ( δ H 3.18, 4) and oxygenated methylene proton ( δ H 3.38, 6) to C-7 ( δ C 81.1 and 79.1, respectively). Likewise, the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 5 were highly similar ( Tables 1 and 2 ) to those of 3 with the addition of a methoxy moiety [ δ H 3.26 and δ C 57.6 (7-OCH 3 )] located at C-7, further confirmed by the HMBC correlations of methoxy proton at ( δ H 3.26) to C-7 ( δ C 81.8) (Fig. S31, Fig. S40 and Fig. S48 Supporting Information). Altogether, 4 and 6 were elucidated as methoxylated and ethoxylated from 2, whereas 5 was methoxylated from 3.

Compounds 2–6 have no Cotton effects in the ECD spectrum, suggesting that these compounds were obtained as racemic compounds. The NOESY correlations between H 2 -1"/H 3 -5" in 2 indicated syn -orientation of these protons. In contrast, anti -orientation was identified in 3 further backed up by the lack of the NOESY correlations between H 2 -1" and H 3 - 5". In addition, DP4 calculations were applied to establish the relative stereochemistry of 2 and 3. As a result, DP4 calculation indicated the structural equivalence of stereoisomer 2"* S ,3"* R ,7* S ,8* S of 2 with 97.6% probability and 2"* S ,3"* S ,7* S ,8* S of 3 with 100% probability (Tables S7 and S8).

Selected compounds (1–5) were evaluated for α- glucosidase inhibitory activity in vitro. Interestingly, all of the tested compounds revealed not only excellent activity with an IC 50 value of 3.6–33.4 μM, but also better activity than the positive control, acarbose (IC 50 93.6 ± 0.5). Among them, 4 and 5 showed the highest inhibitory effect on α- glucosidase with IC 50 values of 3.6 ± 0.4 and 4.3 ± 0.04 μM, respectively, ( Table 3 ). For antioxidant activities of compounds 1–3 and 5–6 evaluating using the DPPH radical scavenging assay with ascorbic acid as the positive control (IC 50 30.2 ± 0.5), 1, 2, 3 and 5 illustrated stronger antioxidant activity than the positive control with the IC 50 values of 13.2 ± 0.7, 20.1 ± 0.4, 19.3 ± 0.5 and 12.8 ± 0.2 μM ( Table 3 ).

In conclusion, six undescribed prenylated chalcones with two unprecedented 2-benzylidene-1-tetralone and bicyclo [3.2.1]octane scaffolds were isolated from the heartwood of
M. gagei
. Interestingly, 2–6 were found as five pairs of enantiomers. In addition, all tested compounds showed potent inhibitory activity against the α- glucosidase from the yeast and antioxidant activity. Among them, 5 not only possessed strong activity against the α- glucosidase with an IC 50 of 4.3 ± 0.04 μM but also potential antioxidant activity with an IC 50 of 12.8 ± 0.2 μM.

The heartwood of
Mansonia gagei J.R.Drumm. (Malvaceae)
was collected in
January 2019
from Muak Lek district , Saraburi province , Thailand (
14 ◦ 26 ′ 27.8"N
,
101 ◦ 22 ′ 22.4"E
). The identity of this plant was compared with voucher specimen No. 43281 at the herbarium of the Royal Forestry Department of Thailand. A voucher for the actual plant was assigned with the code (CUCHEM, 2022–01) and is deposited at the Department of Chemistry , Faculty of Science , Chulalongkorn University
.

The dried milled heartwood of
M. gagei
(15.0 kg) was extracted three times with ethyl acetate (3 × 40 L) at room temperature. The crude EtOAc extract (750.0 g) was fractionated by a silica gel quick column (No. 7729, Merck) using n-hexane-EtOAc (from 85:15 to 0:100, v/v), and acetone as the eluent resulted in five fractions HE1–HE3, EA, Ac. Fraction Ac ( 150.2 g ) was fractionated using silica gel CC with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH of increasing polarity to give four fractions Ac1–Ac4. Fraction Ac2 ( 9.1 g ) was chromatographed on a Sephadex LH-20 column with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (1:1) to obtain three subfractions Ac2.1–Ac2.3. Subfraction Ac2.2 was further purified by RP-18 CC and eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (2:1) to get 4 ( 41 mg ), 5 ( 10 mg ) and 6 ( 6 mg ). Fraction Ac3 ( 22.5 g ), Ac4 (25.0 g) were separated on silica gel CC with n-hexane/ CH 2 Cl 2 /acetone (5:3:2) to get six subfractions Ac3.1–Ac3.3, Ac4.1–Ac4.3, respectively. Subfraction Ac3.3 was subjected to a Sephadex LH-20 with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (1:1), and then an RP-18 CC, eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (2:1) to give 2 ( 30 mg ), and 3 ( 25 mg ). Subfraction Ac4.2 was subjected to silica gel CC eluted with a solvent system nhexane-CH 2 Cl 2 -EtOAc-MeOH (1:2:1:0.2) yield 1 ( 8 mg ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. The proposed biosynthetic pathway of 1–6.
α- Glucosidase inhibitory and antioxidant activities.

subSection.paragraph: Yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 20 + 98 ( c 0.4, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 209 (4.36), 298 (2.56) nm; ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 273 (7.79), 344 (2.42) nm; IR vmax 3268, 2926, 1684, 1587, 1514, 1449, 1089 cm -1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 441.1910, [M + H] + (calcd for C 25 H 29 O 7 , 441.1913).
Pale yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 20 + 2 ( c 1.0, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 207 (4.36), 241 (3.89), 302 (3.82) nm; IR vmax 3331, 2960,

Pale yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 20 + 3 ( c 0.7, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 207 (4.25), 241 (3.86), 302 (3.80) nm; IR vmax 3378, 2927, 1732, 1588, 1517, 1450 cm ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 463.1735, [M + Na] + (calcd for C 25 H 28 O 7 Na, 463.1733).

Yellowish amorphous powder; [ α ] D 20 + 3 ( c 0.2, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 207 (4.19), 239 (3.12) nm; IR vmax 3358, 2932, 1735, 1588, 1518, 1449, 1090 cm -1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 477.1921, [M + Na] + (calcd for C 26 H 30 O 7 Na, 477.1889).

Pale yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 20 + 3 ( c 1.0, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 207 (4.18), 240 (3.02) nm; IR vmax 3389, 2967, 1737, 1588, 1450, 1361 cm -1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 477.1918, [M + Na] + (calcd for C 26 H 30 O 7 Na, 477.1889).

Pale yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 20 + 3 ( c 0.7, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 207 (4.20), 240 (3.36) nm; IR vmax 3357, 2969, 2935, 1739, 1660, 1588, 1449, 1359, 1088 cm -1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 491.2049, [M + Na] + (calcd for C 27 H 32 O 7 Na, 491.2046).

The structures were fully optimised in methanol by using the PCM model at the DFT/B3LYP/6–31++ G (d,p) level in the Gaussian 16 package ( Frisch et al., 2016 ). The DP4 calculation to compare the NMR results between experimental and computational values of 2 and 3 is from Howarth et al. (2020) with an open source available at https://www-jmg.ch.cam.ac.uk/tools/nmr/DP4/. The methanol solvent is also used to perform ECD spectroscopy for compound 1 at the CAM-B3LYP/TZVP level of theory ( Wang et al., 2014 ).
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
The data that has been used is confidential.

In addition, we are also indebted for support from the Thailand Research Fund via Directed Basic Research Grant (Grant no. DBG6180029).
